text: In this video, you’ll see how to manage

apps in the AWS Management 
Console with myApplications.

Using myApplications, you can 
monitor key application metrics,

identify operational issues, and 
optimize your applications for cost
savings, health, security, and performance.

The myApplications experience is available
 in the AWS Management Console Home.
To get started, let’s create an application.
We’ll provide a name and description.
Optionally, we can add tags or attribute groups.
Let’s continue to the next step.
Next, we’ll add resources to our application.

To do so, we need to 
turn on Resource Explorer.

We’ll choose the Quick setup option to 
index all the resources in our AWS account.

Next, we’ll choose an AWS Region to contain the 
aggregator index for all Regions in our account.
Let’s turn on Resource Explorer.
The indexes have been created successfully.
Let’s continue creating our application.
We can now add resources to our application.

All the resources that have been 
indexed within our account are listed here.
We can filter by resource type.

In this case, we’ll add 
an AWS CloudFormation

stack that contains the resources 
required to run our application.

Let’s select the stack to add
 all of the resources within it.
Next, we’ll review the app configuration.

We’ll acknowledge that a CloudFormation 
stack update operation will be performed

to add the AWS application 
tag to the app resources.
Let’s create the application.

A dashboard has been automatically generated 
for our application within myApplications.
Let’s explore its widgets.

The Cost and usage widget 
summarizes AWS resource
costs and usage from AWS Cost Explorer.

To get a more detailed view, we 
can go directly to Cost Explorer.

Here, we can get a more granular look into 
our costs and where they are coming from.
Let’s return to our application dashboard.

The Compute widget provides 
insights that can help us optimize
our application’s compute resources.
If AWS Security Hub is enabled,

the Security widget displays the 
highest priority security findings.
To view more details, let’s go to Security Hub.
The findings are filtered to our application.

We can drill into any of 
the findings to learn more.
Let’s look at the first one.

In this case, some EC2 instances 
have been flagged as non-compliant.

The details include a description 
of the finding and its severity,

where the instances are 
located, and remediation steps.

The Monitoring and Operations widget 
displays alarms and alerts for resources

associated with our application, service 
level objectives (SLOs), and standardized

application performance metrics 
from CloudWatch Application Signals.

We can go to CloudWatch to set 
up monitoring for our application.

These are the applications that 
are being monitored and managed.
Let’s drill into our application.

This page displays an application 
summary, as well as the metrics and
alarms associated with the application.
We can also add or remove metrics from here.

Let’s return to the myApplications 
dashboard one more time.

The DevOps widget shows how many 
EC2 instances are being managed and
what their config compliance status is.

Finally, we can use the Tags widget 
to assist in reviewing and applying
tags to our application resources.

You’ve just seen how to manage apps in the 
AWS Management Console with myApplications

You can learn more about this topic in 
the description and links for this video.
Thanks for watching. Now it’s your turn to try.
